head.supplied: 10th August 1857 ¶ Sir, ¶ ¶ The Chief Secretary of South Australia intimated that the Superintendent of the Botanic Gardens there has forwarded p post a parcel addressed to you containing eighty five...

div.p: No. 57/2453, unit 3, p. 409, VPRS 975/P1 outward registered correspondence, VA 669 Public Works Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

On 17 April 1856 the Chief Secretary of SA forwarded a letter from the Chairman of the Adelaide Botanic Gardens Committee requesting information about the Melbourne Botanic Gardens and an exchange of seed. The letter was passed to the Public Works Department on 28 April 1856 (No. 3351, vol. 1857 V, VPRS 1186, PROV).
On 18 June the following year the President of the Board of Land and Works, D. Moore, forwarded to the Chief Secretary, W. Haines, 'a package containing eighty six varieties of plants, from the Botanic Gardens, Melbourne. I have also to forward replies to the enquiries contained in the letter of the Chairman of the Adelaide Botanic Gardens Committee, together with a catalogue of Plants &c under cultivation here [B57.13.07]. I may mention that the delay which has occurred in replying to the communication under notice arose in consequence of it being necessary that the Catalogue should be revised, previous to being printed, by the Government Botanist, for which purpose it was withheld until that officers return from his tour in Northern Australia.' (B57/4434, unit 861, VPRS 1189, PROV). The Under Secretary, J. Moore, forwarded the package of seeds, the replies to questions and the catalogue of plants to Adelaide on 30 June 1857 (No. 1305, unit 1, p. 463, VPRS 1187, PROV).
On 30 July 1857 the Chief Secretary, SA informed Haines that the Superintendent of the Adelaide Botanic Gardens, G. Francis, would be forwarding a parcel containing 85 varieties of South African seeds to M (A57/5560, unit 861, VPRS 1189, PROV). On 29 July, M wrote to Francis acknowledging receipt of the package. 10th August 1857

The Chief Secretary of South Australia intimated that the Superintendent of the Botanic Gardens there has forwarded p post a parcel addressed to you containing eighty five varieties of South African seeds. I have the honor to request you will state whether such parcel has been received.
See M to D. Moore, 13 August 1857 (in this edition as 57-08-13a).
